author: Nasiru Eneji Abdulrasheed
title: Gombe State Driver's 700km Trek to Abuja Celebrates CDS General Musa's Leadership
text:
In an extraordinary display of gratitude and respect, 29-year-old Suleiman Rabiu from Gombe State embarked on a remarkable 700-kilometre journey on foot to the nation's capital, Abuja. Setting out on February 12, 2024, and arriving on February 28, Rabiu's 16-day odyssey through challenging weather was inspired by his admiration for the leadership of Chief of Defence Staff, General Christopher Gwabin Musa. His journey underscores the significant improvements in national security and the deep personal connections some citizens feel towards military leadership.
Unwavering Determination and Admirable Leadership
Rabiu's trek was motivated by what he perceives as transformative leadership by General CG Musa, particularly in enhancing the security of lives and property across Nigeria. Highlighting the General's people-centric approach, Rabiu felt compelled to express his gratitude in person for the successes achieved under Musa's command across various operational areas. This journey, according to Rabiu, also symbolizes the improved security situation that now facilitates travel that would have been perilous due to insecurity, especially in the Northeast region.
A Warm Welcome and Affirmation of Commitment
Upon reaching Abuja, Rabiu was warmly received by Acting Director of Defence Information, Brigadier General Tukur Gusau, Assistant Director of Defence Headquarters Provost, Major Nneka Olima, and Special Assistant to the CDS, Alhaji Hashim Hussaini. Brigadier General Gusau commended Rabiu's resilience and support for the military, acknowledging his special connection with the Chief of Defence Staff. He reassured Rabiu and the public of the Armed Forces' unwavering commitment to maintaining security, prioritizing the welfare of the people, and upholding democratic principles in line with the President's Renewed Hope agenda.
Reflections on a Journey of Gratitude and Hope
Rabiu's journey from Gombe to Abuja is more than a story of individual endurance; it is a testament to the impact of effective leadership on the lives of citizens and the importance of acknowledging such impacts in meaningful ways. His actions highlight a unique form of civic engagement and underscore the potential for improved security to empower individuals to express their gratitude and support for their leaders. As Rabiu's footsteps echo in the corridors of power, they remind us of the vital connection between those who serve and those they are sworn to protect.
